p: Governments, institutions, and communities manage the risks associated with extreme precipitation by establishing design and performance standards for buildings, dams, levees, and other infrastructure, as well as by placing restrictions on where and how development can take place (Crichton, 2008; Kundzewicz & Takeuchi, 1999; Tollan, 2002). These standards and guidelines are built, however, entirely on observations of the historical past, and therefore if the frequency and magnitude of extreme precipitation events change, these standards could lead to inadequate preparation for future risks (Herring et al., 2015; Maxwell et al., 2018; Wobus et al., 2017).
